caption:
Adult children caring for their aging parents are worried about unreliable agencies, dwindling financial resources and a lack of resources for long-term care.

The New York Times and @kffhealthnews, a nonprofit news organization, interviewed families and experts for the “Dying Broke” series, a joint project on long-term care. Those taking care of their parents expressed concern as they watched bills pile up and found themselves having to make difficult decisions about placing their parents in assisted living facilities. “If Mom gets worse and I can’t care for her? That’s something I struggle with,” said Karina Ortega, whose mother was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s in March 2020. She added: “I just can’t see it in me to leave my mom because she needs me.”

Read more at the link in our bio about how adult children are coping with helping their aging parents. Photos by @maansi.photo, @ddrios, @bryan.meltz, @kelburgess, @willcrooksphoto and @michelleagins

The Israeli military forged ahead with its raid on Gaza’s largest hospital Wednesday afternoon, 12 hours after troops first stormed the complex, in a significant step that could shape the pace and extent of its war with Hamas.

The hospital, Al-Shifa, has become synonymous with Israel’s 40-day effort to wrest control of Gaza from Hamas. Its capture could affect international sentiment about the invasion as well as the continuing negotiations to free the hostages captured by Hamas last month.

A senior Israeli military official said on Wednesday that troops were interrogating people inside the hospital and had found weapons during the raid, but declined to provide evidence or further details because the operation was ongoing. Palestinian officials, the heads of United Nations agencies and some Mideast regional leaders condemned the raid, warning that it risked the lives of Gaza’s most vulnerable.

Few details about the raid were available on Wednesday afternoon, as communications were disrupted in Gaza City. This is a developing story. Tap the link in our bio for live updates.

Hochatown, on the shores of Broken Bow Lake in the southeast corner of Oklahoma, has a population of just 219 people. But on weekends, as many as 50,000 visitors, mostly from Dallas, flock there to kayak, fly-fish and hike among the waterfalls, rapids and thick forests of pine and pawpaw trees.

Before the Covid-19 pandemic, Hochatown had roughly 400 cabins for rent on Airbnb. There are now more than 2,400 — a staggering 413% increase in five years. Hochatown does not have a single police officer or professional firefighter. There is no sewerage system, no garbage collection, not even sufficient water to handle the proliferation of people and new homes.

What might be called the Airbnb effect has transformed the landscapes — and the economies — of countless small towns across the U.S. Read the full story at the link in our bio. Photos by @shelby_tauber

Booths, a small chain that has sold groceries in northern England since 1847, announced this week that it would be getting rid of the self-checkouts in all but two of its 28 stores. The chain is bucking a trend that has remade retail shopping around the world over the last 20 years. Booths, which has about 3,000 employees, said in a statement that having its employees interact with customers would provide a better experience.

Do you prefer a cashier to self-checkout? Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the reversal of the self-checkout trend. Photo by @andrew_testa

Families of Hostages Held by Hamas Begin March From Tel Aviv to Jerusalem

About 100 people who are family members and friends of the hostages held by Hamas began a five-day march to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office in Jerusalem.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the families who are seeking to secure the release of people abducted in the Oct. 7 attack on Israel.

Doctors have long relied on a few key patient characteristics to assess risk of a heart attack or stroke, using a calculus that considers blood pressure, cholesterol, smoking and diabetes status, as well as demographics: age, sex and race.

Now, the American Heart Association is taking race out of the equation.

The overhaul of the widely used cardiac-risk algorithm is an acknowledgment that, unlike sex or age, race identification in and of itself is not a biological risk factor.

Learn more about the revision, as well as a broader trend toward removing race from a variety of clinical algorithms within the U.S. health care system, at the link in our bio. Photo by Rocketclips, Inc./Alamy

A Volcano May Erupt in Iceland

Iceland is bracing for a possible volcanic eruption. Since late October, tens of thousands of earthquakes have been reported in the Reykjanes Peninsula, in the southwestern part of the country. At one point there were as many as 1,400 in a single 24-hour period.

On Tuesday, the Icelandic Met Office, the country’s weather service, warned that there was a “significant likelihood of a volcanic eruption in the coming days.” The increased seismic activity and the formation of a nine-mile underground river of magma have led the authorities in recent days to declare a state of emergency and to evacuate the small fishing town of Grindavik, where more than 3,000 people live.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about what to expect in the event of a volcanic eruption in Iceland.

Wondering which turkey is right for your Thanksgiving table? We’ve got you covered. At the link in bio, find an interactive guide that’ll walk you through choosing a turkey (or turkey alternatives), sides and everything else you’ll need for the big day.

The U.S. has no coherent system for providing long-term elder care, leaving aging people to rely on a patchwork of solutions. Millions of families are facing daunting life choices and potential financial ruin as the escalating costs of care devour their savings and incomes.

The private market where a minuscule portion of families buys long-term care insurance has shriveled.  Labor shortages have left families searching for workers willing to care for their elders at home.The cost of a spot in an assisted-living facility has soared to an unaffordable level for most middle-class Americans who qualify for nursing home care paid for by the government only after they run out of money. 

The prospect of dying broke looms as an imminent threat for the boomer generation, which has vastly expanded the middle class and looked hopefully toward a comfortable retirement on the backbone of 401(k)s and pensions. The problem is only set to worsen: By 2050, the population of Americans 65 and older is projected to increase by more than 50%, to 86 million, according to census estimates. The number of people 85 or older will nearly triple, to 19 million.

The New York Times and @kffhealthnews, a nonprofit news organization, interviewed dozens of families and experts for the “Dying Broke” series, a joint project on long-term care. Read more at the link in our bio. Photos by @shuranhuang, @arinyoon, @fremson and @willdeshazer

More than 400 political appointees and staff members representing some 40 government agencies sent a letter to President Biden on Tuesday protesting his support of Israel in its war in Gaza.

The letter, part of growing internal dissent over the administration’s support of the war, calls on the president to seek an immediate cease-fire in the Gaza Strip and to push Israel to allow humanitarian aid into the territory. It is the latest of several protest letters from officials throughout the Biden administration, including three internal memos to Secretary of State Antony Blinken signed by dozens of State Department employees as well as an open letter signed by more than 1,000 employees of the U.S. Agency for International Development.

The letter, a copy of which was reviewed by The New York Times, began by denouncing the Oct. 7 attacks by Hamas, then urged Biden to stop the bloodshed caused by Israel’s retaliatory military campaign in Gaza. Read the full story at the link in our bio

Six trees made famous by the series “Game of Thrones” will be cut down in the coming weeks, officials in Northern Ireland said on Monday.

The trees are part of the Dark Hedges, an international tourist attraction for fans of the HBO series. The beech trees, which form an arch over a road with long branches that twist up to the sky, have become one of the most photographed spots in Northern Ireland, with hundreds of tourists visiting on some days.

The trees that make up the Dark Hedges, which sit on privately owned land, were planted by the Stuart family in the 18th century. There were originally about 150 trees, but today just 86 remain, with some having been damaged in storms or by rot.

Read more about the Dark Hedges at the link in our bio. Photo by @hazelthompsonphoto
Watch @ericjoonho make his version of green bean casserole after testing 13 recipes. Tap the link in bio to check it out, now on YouTube.

Gaza Hospitals ‘Must Be Protected,’ Biden Says

The Gaza Strip’s hospitals “must be protected,” President Joe Biden said on Monday as Israeli troops battled to seize control of what Israel says is a Hamas command complex that lies below the enclave’s main medical facility, Al-Shifa Hospital.

Thousands of people fled Al-Shifa over the weekend as Israeli troops encircled it. On Monday, the World Health Organization warned of a “dire and perilous” situation for patients. The health organization said in a statement that Al-Shifa “is not functioning as a hospital anymore,” after having run out of fuel and water, putting the lives of patients at risk.

For the latest updates, tap the link in our bio.

Around 53 million Americans are caregivers for a family member or friend with a health issue or disability, and nearly a third spend 20 or more hours a week in that role. Looking after a sick family member can mean putting your own life on hold, often with little recognition or outside support.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which calls caregivers the “backbone” of long-term home care in the U.S., has warned that caregivers face many risks, including anxiety, depression, chronic health conditions and financial strain. Yet experts said that many caregivers feel they cannot speak openly about their frustration and anger, and that it is important to normalize those feelings.

Read more about the quiet rage of caregivers — and how some seek community support — at the link in our bio. Photos by @markabramsonphoto

Gaza’s main hospital is “no longer functioning,” according to the World Health Organization, which warned of a “dire and perilous” situation for hundreds of patients and displaced people trapped inside as Israeli troops battle Hamas fighters nearby.

Dozens of corpses are decomposing at the Al-Shifa Hospital because there is no way to preserve or remove them, a head nurse and a health official said.

The hospital and other medical centers in Gaza City had been struggling for weeks to maintain operations as supplies of fuel and medicine dwindled. The Health Ministry, which is controlled by Hamas, said on Monday that Israeli military vehicles had advanced to the gates of the hospital complex.

Patients at Al-Shifa have been dying because of a lack of power, according to doctors and Gazan health officials. Jihan Miqdad, a head nurse in the emergency room at Al-Shifa, said in a phone interview on Monday that patients who were on life support in the intensive care unit were dying because there was no oxygen.

“The situation here is catastrophic in every sense of the word,” she said.

Israeli security officials say that Hamas has built a vast command complex under the hospital, making it a legitimate military target. Hamas has denied the allegations, as has Al-Shifa’s director, Dr. Mohammed Abu Salmiya, who has called them “untrue.”

A spokesman for the Gazan Health Ministry, Dr. ​​Medhat Abbas, said in a phone interview that more than 100 bodies were lying in the hospital’s front yard, another 50 were inside and around 60 were in the morgue.

This is a developing story. For the latest updates go to the link in our bio.

Understanding the reality of Texas matters. With a population of over 30 million, the state is increasingly shaping the cultural and political direction of the country. Its economy is one of the largest in the world, growing faster than even the nation’s.

Texas has long been defined by demographic changes, particularly its expanding Hispanic population. But the nature of those changes, and how profound they have become, has often been misunderstood, even by those who follow the state closely.

The New York Times collected years of census data, analyzed migration patterns and traveled to communities across Texas to understand what is happening in the state – the nation’s second most populous – a place that offers an important window into the future of both national politics and the attempts to deal with questions of identity and diversity.

Read more about how Texas is changing at the link in our bio. Photos by @ddrios, @meridithkohut and @townsend.___

South Africa is the most industrialized African country and was once considered an economic success story. But it has one of the highest youth unemployment rates in the world: 61% of people aged 15 to 24 are unemployed. The overall unemployment rate is 33%, and for high school graduates it’s 35%.

If South Africa, which has the most developed economy in Africa, cannot create enough jobs, economists warn, then how are poorer countries on the continent going to generate opportunities for their booming youth populations?

Read part two of a series on how the African youth boom is changing the continent, and beyond, at the link in our bio. Reporting by @lynseychutel and photographs by @gulshanii

Working on a remote island, scientists think they can use genetic engineering to block a malaria-carrying species of mosquito from spreading the disease — and do it in just a few months. But governments are wary. Our global health reporter, @snolenglobal, reported this story from the country of São Tomé and Príncipe in the Gulf of Guinea.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about this experiment. Video by Stephanie Nolen and Karen Hanley/The New York Times

In the Rockaways, a low-lying peninsula in Queens that separates the Atlantic Ocean from Jamaica Bay, life has long been shaped by the tides. High-tide floods are not caused by the weather but by the twice monthly alignment of the Earth, sun and moon. When there is a full or new moon, the sun and moon exert a gravitational pull that forces tides to swell.

But as climate change causes sea levels to rise, high-tide floods — sometimes called nuisance floods or sunny-day floods because they can happen on clear days — are likely to inundate more coastal neighborhoods across the five boroughs.

As high-tide floods become more frequent, New Yorkers are asking themselves: When does a place become unlivable? Tap the link in our bio to read more about the problem and how the city is responding. Photos by @dave_sanders

Army Ammunition Plant Is Tied to Mass Shootings Across the U.S.

Lake City Army Ammunition Plant in Independence, Missouri, was built during World War II and has made nearly all the rifle cartridges used by the U.S. military since it pulled out of Vietnam.

In recent years, it has also pumped billions of rounds of military-grade ammunition into the commercial market, an investigation by The New York Times found, leaving the “LC” signature scattered across crime scenes, including the sites of some of the nation’s most heinous mass shootings.

The plant, operated by a private contractor with Army oversight, is now one of the country’s biggest manufacturers of commercial rounds for the popular AR-15, and it remains so even as the U.S. government supplies ammunition to Ukraine.

A vast majority of Lake City rounds sold by retailers have been purchased by law-abiding citizens, including hunters, farmers and target shooters. Some of those people are drawn to the ammunition because it’s made with the same materials, and often to the same specifications, as the military’s. Others see the rounds as authentic accessories for their tactical weapons and gear.

But more than one million pages of search warrants, police evidence logs, ballistics reports, forfeiture records and court proceedings compiled by The Times provide a sweeping accounting of how Lake City ammunition, once intended for war, has also cut a criminal path through towns and cities in nearly all 50 states.

Read more about the findings at the link in our bio.

Video by Ben Dooley, @claire_sandwich and @ekrhyne

Chelsie Hill was a champion dancer when a night in February 2010 changed her life. She was in a serious car accident that left her with severe spinal injuries and unable to move her lower body.

Hill is the founder of the Rollettes, a dance team formed in 2012 for women who use wheelchairs. They perform all over the country and host an annual empowerment weekend in Los Angeles for women with disabilities called the Rollettes Experience.

Reclaiming her story as both a dancer and a wheelchair user meant finding others like her. She achieved what she set out to do, creating an unrepentantly girlie sisterhood that supports others.

Read more about @chelsiehill and the @rollettes_la at the link in our bio. Photos by @magdawosinskastudio

This post has been edited to correct a timeline discrepancy.

Where do we go when we die? 

For these seven people, the answer is space. They have chosen to send their ashes, or a sample of their DNA, into orbit, to the moon or simply hurtling into space. They settled on their final wishes for different reasons: spiritual, pragmatic, romantic. Many consider it the culmination of a lifelong fascination with space exploration, the impulse to look up with wonder. Lemuel Patterson, 71 (Photo 1), has always been enraptured by space and wants to be buried up there.  For others, a space burial signals acceptance of the idea that, in the end, there may be only a void awaiting us. 

To read their stories, tap the link in our bio. Photos by @dina_litovsky

The new crop of e-cigarettes represents an about-face from the more subdued look of its predecessors. That has experts concerned.

The understated look associated with Juul has been supplanted by the rounded, vivid designs of Elf Bars and other brands, whose color schemes often correspond with their flavors. Some public health experts are concerned that these devices’ playful appearance — which is neatly in line with the maximalist aesthetic preferences of many members of Gen Z — may offer appealing new cover for nicotine products.

Each Elf Bar contains as much nicotine as 590 cigarettes, according to one estimate. Doctors say that nicotine is especially addictive for young people, and research suggests that teenage vapers risk both immediate and long-term lung damage.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how these products are geared to catch the eyes of young people. Photo illustration and photos by @ok__mccausland

Vietnam is having a cable car bonanza. The country is home to four of the longest cable cars in the world, and some 26 cable car lines have been built in a dozen locations across Vietnam over the past two decades.

Vietnam’s abundance of mountains, jungles and islands makes cable cars a natural fit since they can be built faster, cheaper and with less environmental damage than roads. But the cable cars are typically parts of mass-tourism complexes, and some travelers, citizens and environmental activists see them as scars on the landscape and a symptom of rampant overdevelopment by powerful conglomerates. Environmentalists are also anxious over the vision for Cat Ba Island from the Sun Group, one of the communist country’s biggest real estate and tourism developers. The on-again, off-again plans include a network of cable cars, a resort, a golf course and a cruise ship port, all in an area designated by UNESCO as a Biosphere Reserve.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about this booming mode of transportation in Vietnam. Photos by @askmott

‘Is It Good Enough to Fool My Gallerist?’

David Salle, one of America’s most thoughtful painters, hoped an AI program could nourish creativity. For nearly a year, the painter has tried to defy conventional thinking about generative artificial intelligence by testing an AI program’s capacity to become a sophisticated creator of art.

Salle held weekly meetings with two technologists, Danika Laszuk and Grant Davis, who tailored a text-to-image model to the painter’s requirements, relying on descriptive prompts that generated images in the artist’s style. The New York Times observed three of their work sessions, tracking the algorithm’s progress over several months as it adopted more of Salle’s techniques and abandoned the bland photorealism that often limits other generative programs.

Tap the link in our bio for more from Zachary Small, a culture reporter for The New York Times, who explained Salle’s approach to AI. Video by @zacharyhsmall, @claire_sandwich and @rurukuooo

Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour officially went global on Thursday when the pop megastar began a new phase of shows that would take her to 25 cities across South America, Asia, Australia and Europe over the next 10 months.

Since March, the North American stretch of the tour has become an economic marvel and a cultural force, cementing Swift’s status as one of the most influential, and beloved, people on the continent. Now, she is set to demonstrate that her fame and adoration go well beyond borders.

There are few countries better to display the intense passion of her fans than Argentina. While Swift has become a certified global icon, Argentina has become known for worshiping icons with religious fervor.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the dedicated Swifties in Argentina. Photos by @_sarahpabst_

They Left Gaza to Work in Israel. Now They’re Stranded.

Thousands of workers from Gaza have been trapped in the West Bank since the Hamas attacks on Oct. 7. Their Israeli work permits have been canceled, and they’re deeply worried about their families back home. “I have no idea if my own four kids are alive or dead,” Jihad Al-Aaf, one Gazan worker trapped in the West Bank, said. “I try calling, but they don’t answer.”

Video by Matthew Cassel, Ayman Abu Ramouz and Caroline Kim

Nearly a million miles away, the James Webb telescope just took a picture. Since transmitting its first data, it has made stunning discoveries, including a plume of water spanning 6,000 miles and a galaxy that formed more than 13 billion years ago.

The telescope is an engineering marvel: Its massive mirror makes it possible to collect light from the faintest objects. It has multiple ways of blocking and dissecting that light, giving us detailed portraits of distant galaxies and close neighbors alike.

What’s it showing us about the future of cosmology – and our own past? ​​Tap the link in our bio to find out. From @nytmag with photos by @nasa
It's getting chilly out there, and you know what that means: @clarkbar's Mushroom Bourguignon. Recipe is at the link in bio! Photo by @dmalosh, with food styling by @simoncooks

Barry Manilow is finally getting his wish: a Broadway show.

The musical, “Harmony,” tells the story of the Comedian Harmonists, a singing group torn apart by the rise of Nazism and World War II. It is a decades-in-the-making labor of love for Manilow and his longtime collaborator Bruce Sussman, who first conceived of the show in the early 1990s. 

“Harmony” debuted in San Diego in 1997 to mixed reviews, and failed to transfer. A planned Broadway run evaporated when financial backing disintegrated. Many iterations of the musical followed, but Broadway deals fell apart. “It was so heartbreaking every time it didn’t make it,” Manilow, the singer, said in an interview. Now, the musical will at last have its moment on the Great White Way. 

Tap the link in our bio to read about the many iterations of “Harmony” and how it finally made it to Broadway. Photo by @evelynfreja

If you feel as though your pain is being ignored before, during or after a procedure, what do you do? Here are some tips on ways to advocate for yourself when speaking with a doctor.

Video by @caron_nyt , @claire_sandwich, @rurukuooo, Rebecca Suner

Burned out from life in New York, the photographer @irjaliinapaavonpera traveled to northern Chile to study the ancient wisdom of the Lickanantay, the area’s Indigenous people. Here’s what she saw.

Tap the link in our bio to read about her experience and see more photos.

The Signs Were All There. Why Did No One Stop the Maine Shooter?

The shooter who killed 18 people with an assault-style rifle in Lewiston, Maine, displayed a textbook set of warning signs: He was hearing voices. He told people that he was planning violence. And his behavior had markedly changed in the months leading up to the mass shooting he carried out last month.

His family, his superiors in the military and the local police knew all of this. Yet no one stopped him.

Read more at the link in our bio. Video by Shaila Dewan and Claire Hogan

After a long career as America’s most famous and least likely sex counselor, Dr. Ruth Westheimer has turned her attention to the epidemic of loneliness in the U.S. Last year, she set out to become the Loneliness Ambassador for New York State.

Loneliness has been on the rise since before the pandemic but escalated because of lockdowns and social distancing requirements. In May, the U.S. surgeon general issued an advisory that isolation can be just as deadly as smoking up to 15 cigarettes a day and can pose a greater risk to longevity than being sedentary or obese. 

But when Dr. Westheimer began her quest for the job, no such position existed. Tap the link in our bio to learn how she got it. Photos by @gabbyjones.jpeg

At times, Washington, D.C. can feel like a tale of two cities: politicians and temporary dwellers versus multigenerational residents fighting to hold on to their piece of the district.
 
Once known as “Chocolate City” because of its predominantly African American population, Washington has seen its demographics shift dramatically in recent decades, bringing both positive and negative effects of gentrification. The second phase of the Wharf district, a $3.6 billion development, has contributed a new Pendry luxury hotel and splashy dining destinations, all set against the backdrop of skyrocketing living costs (only recently cooling), increased crime and ongoing questions of cultural identity. But even in this time of transition, Washington is still a hub of art, history and social justice leadership, and is home to many of the best free museums and monuments in the world.

Ready to spend a weekend in the nation’s capital? We have your itinerary ready to go. Tap the link in our bio to see what else we have planned. Photos by @julia.nikhinson

New York City is legally obligated to provide a bed for every homeless person who asks for one, under a decades-old court settlement. But 18 months into a migrant crisis that shows no signs of abating, it has walked away from its obligation, at least for some people.

The city, which is currently providing emergency shelter to more than 65,000 migrants, is no longer guaranteeing beds for single adults who have hit the city’s 30-day or 60-day limit on stays at any one migrant shelter.

Read the full story at the link in our bio. Video by @andylocal2, @rebeccasuner, @globalgabrielgrey

Senator Joe Manchin, the conservative West Virginia Democrat known for bipartisan deal-making and often being a thorn in the side of his party, announced on Thursday that he would not seek re-election, dealing a blow to Democrats’ chances of holding the Senate next year.

Instead, Manchin, who was likely to face a strong Republican challenger to keep his Senate seat in a deeply red state, suggested he would continue exploring whether there was an appetite in the country for a centrist third-party bid for the presidency. That prospect has alarmed many Democrats, who fear such a run could doom President Biden’s hopes of remaining in the White House.

This is a developing story. Tap the link in our bio to read the full story. Photo by @kenny_holston

At the third Republican primary debate on Wednesday, five Republican presidential candidates delivered pointed criticism of one another — in addition to President Biden and Donald Trump — in an effort to stand out to voters as the first nominating contests draw near.

The rivals, all running well behind  Trump — who once again declined to participate — made the case for their candidacies on issues including foreign policy, abortion and the economy, often talking over one another as they tried to promote themselves and take one another down. In the process, they employed facts that were occasionally true, sometimes misleading and occasionally downright false.

Here is a fact-check of some of their statements. Read more fact-checks of the GOP debate at the link in our bio.

Tracy Chapman became the first Black songwriter to win song of the year at the Country Music Awards for “Fast Car,” a folk ballad that topped the country charts more than three decades after it was first released, thanks in part to a cover by the singer Luke Combs.

Chapman did not attend the awards ceremony on Wednesday in Nashville but thanked the crowd in a statement that was read on stage by Sarah Evans, a co-presenter of the award.

“It’s truly an honor for my song to be newly recognized after 35 years of its debut,” Chapman’s statement said. “Thank you to the CMAs and a special thanks to Luke and all of the fans of ‘Fast Car.’”

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the award. Photo by Bryan Bedder/Getty Images

With so much hinging on refilling the ranks, efforts are underway to draw more Ukrainian women into the army. Volunteer groups offering all-female training are supporting the effort.

About 43,000 women now serve in the Ukrainian military, according to the ministry of defense, an increase of about 40% since 2021, the year before Russia’s full-scale invasion. Ukrainian women are in combat in southeastern Ukraine now. After the invasion, the military abolished restrictions that kept women from roles such as machine gunner, tank commander and sniper, and lifted rules prohibiting women from driving trucks. It raised the age limit for female recruits, previously 40, to 60, the same as for men.

“The gender of a warrior makes no difference,” said Darya Trebukh, the founder of the nongovernmental group, Ukrainian Valkiriya, that is leading the training sessions.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full story. Photos by @hoffmanbrendan

“Thanksgiving is a major production if you’re the host, and generally I encourage cutting a few corners,” Claire Saffitz writes. “But I draw the line at dessert.”

“As a baker, I give my all to the pie spread, making my own crusts, assembling fillings from scratch and softly whipping fresh cream for serving. No matter the number of guests we’re expecting, I insist on preparing the pie trifecta (pie-fecta?) of apple, pumpkin and pecan, with some twists.” 

@csaffitz’s updated classics and brand-new favorites are ready for your Thanksgiving table: There’s a pecan slab pie, a cranberry cheesecake tart, a caramelized apple pie, a pumpkin pie with pepitas and a creamy lemon pie with honey and ginger. Make one or all five.

All the recipes, plus her method for a foolproof pie dough she spent years developing, are at the link in bio.

Photo: @armandorafaelphotography, food styling: @lpelican

Third GOP Debate: Haley and DeSantis Take Leading Roles

The third Republican presidential debate on Wednesday devolved at times into brutal personal attacks as the five candidates onstage tried to discuss high-minded issues from the fate of Social Security to the role of America abroad between cutting asides and provocative insults.

The most heated exchange came over the unlikely issue of TikTok. After Vivek Ramaswamy bragged about using the Chinese-owned social media network to broadcast his message, he turned to his adversary, Nikki Haley, and mocked her daughter for using the app.

But the debate did address weighty issues: whether a soaring budget deficit required a higher retirement age for access to Social Security and Medicare, how the U.S. should back Israel against Hamas and Ukraine against Russia, and how a president could immediately address the strain of inflation in everyday life.

Tap the link in our bio to read more from Wednesday’s GOP debate.

One of the longest labor crises in Hollywood history is finally coming to an end.

SAG-AFTRA, the union representing tens of thousands of actors, reached a tentative deal for a new contract with entertainment companies on Wednesday, clearing the way for the $134 billion American movie and television business to swing back into motion.

Hollywood’s assembly lines have been at a near-standstill since May because of a pair of strikes by writers and actors, resulting in financial pain for studios and for many of the two million Americans — makeup artists, set builders, location scouts, chauffeurs, casting directors — who work in jobs directly or indirectly related to making TV shows and films.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the actors union and entertainment companies agreed to a deal.

Five candidates kicked off the third Republican presidential debate in Miami on Wednesday, discussing abortion, foreign policy and the economy.

The changing landscape will most likely alter the strategic calculations of the candidates who qualified under the Republican National Committee rules: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor; Ron DeSantis, the Florida governor; Chris Christie, the former New Jersey governor; Vivek Ramaswamy, an entrepreneur; and Tim Scott, the South Carolina senator. Former president Donald Trump did not participate in the debate.

Tap the link in our bio for live updates with reporters and editors from The New York Times. Photos by @scottymacphoto and @maansi.photo

Support for Israel to Take Center Stage at GOP Debate

Israel’s war in Gaza has become a major focus of the 2024 Republican presidential race. While the Republican Party is more unified in its support for Israel (in contrast with the Democratic Party), the conflict has prompted some of the field’s sharpest criticism of former President Donald Trump, who will not be attending for the third debate in a row.
New York Times political correspondent Lisa Lerer reports on how that’s likely to play out at the next debate.

Tap the link in our bio to read the five things to watch at the third GOP presidential debate. Video by Lisa Lerer, Mark Boyer and Kassie Bracken/The New York Times

Shell email accounts, phantom truckers, supply-chain fraud and one seriously bewildered cargo freight broker. This is the long, strange story of one stolen load of valuable cargo in the form of 55,000 rare Kit Kats.

Sought-after Kit Kat flavors like melon, matcha latte and daifuku mochi are a booming business. In Japan, enthusiasts clamor for the rarer flavors, with some sold for just a few weeks or only in a specific region. In the United States, obsessives fawn over the collectibles, comparing reviews on Japanese snack blogs and shelling out for limited editions.

Danny Taing, the founder of a New York company that sells Japanese snacks in subscription boxes, had bought $110,000 worth of the sweets, expecting to make about $250,000 in total revenue. The shipment arrived Stateside from Japan, but somewhere along its cross-country journey, it went missing. What happened?

Tap the link in bio to read more from @amelia.nierenberg about how a load of rare Kit Kats became the object of an elaborate cargo theft, a growing area of crime in the U.S. 

Photo by @adamamengual

A looming rematch next year between President Biden and former President Donald Trump has left voters deeply dissatisfied with their options, longing for alternatives and curious about independent candidates like Robert F. Kennedy Jr., according to new polls of six battleground states conducted by The New York Times and Siena College.

Both Biden and Trump are viewed unfavorably by a majority of voters in these states, one-fifth of voters don’t like either of them, and enthusiasm about the coming election is down sharply compared with a poll conducted before the 2020 contest.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full analysis.

Ohio Vote Continues a Winning Streak for Abortion Rights

In Ohio, a ballot measure establishing a right to abortion in the State Constitution won in an election on Tuesday by a double-digit margin, a striking demonstration of support for abortion rights in a conservative state that Donald Trump won twice by convincing margins.

The results amounted to a resounding victory for abortion rights, proving once again that the issue can energize a broad coalition of Democrats, independents and even some moderate Republicans.

Tap the link in our bio to read more from the election.

The House of Representatives voted on Tuesday to censure Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan and the sole Palestinian American in Congress, formally rebuking her for her statements regarding the Israel-Hamas war.

Twenty-two Democrats joined most Republicans to pass the resolution, which accuses Tlaib of “promoting false narratives” surrounding Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel and of “calling for the destruction of the state of Israel.” The vote was 234 to 188. Four Republicans voted against censuring Tlaib, while one Democrat and three Republicans voted “present,” declining to take a position.

After the gavel fell, Democratic lawmakers, mostly progressives, surrounded Tlaib on the House floor and embraced her.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full story.

Yusef Salaam, who was one of five Black and Latino teenagers convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park and exonerated decades later, was elected on Tuesday night to represent Harlem in the New York City Council.

Salaam, who ran unopposed, had won a commanding victory in a contested Democratic primary in June, when he defeated two sitting members of the New York State Assembly. The Democratic incumbent who currently holds the Council seat, Kristin Richardson Jordan, dropped out of the race before the primary.

Salaam, 49, spoke frequently during his campaign about his conviction, exoneration and persecution by former President Donald Trump, who took out full-page ads in The New York Times and other papers calling for the reinstatement of the death penalty in response to the case of the Central Park jogger.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about Salaam and to see more election results. Photo by @saranaomiphoto

Cherelle Parker, a longtime state and local elected official who promised Philadelphia residents that she would aggressively tackle the city’s crime woes, was elected mayor Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, making her the first woman voted into the city’s highest office.

Viewed as more moderate than the other candidates in the Democratic primary in May, Parker, 51, pledged to hire hundreds more police officers and bring back what she called “constitutional” stop-and-frisk tactics. With registered Democrats vastly outnumbering Republicans in the city — the nation’s sixth most populous, with 1.6 million residents — Parker’s primary win gave her a significant advantage over the Republican nominee, David Oh, a former colleague of hers on the City Council.

Parker, a lifelong Philadelphian, will be the city’s 100th mayor. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Parker and her historic win. Photo by @hanloveyoon

On Wednesday, the Smithsonian’s National Zoo in Washington, D.C., will say goodbye to a family of giant pandas. 

Mei Xiang and Tian Tian, and their 3-year-old cub, Xiao Qi Ji, are scheduled to be loaded into crates and driven in trucks to a FedEx Boeing 777 called the Panda Express. They will then be flown 19 hours from Dulles International Airport to China, where they will join about 150 other pandas in a lush nature preserve in the misty mountains of Sichuan Province.

Giant pandas have been a fixture in Washington since 1972, when China sent the U.S. two pandas after Patricia Nixon, the first lady, mentioned her fondness for pandas to China’s premier during the landmark visit she and Richard Nixon made to Beijing. But U.S.-China tensions have been rising for years, and now there is speculation that China is asking for the return of the pandas because of the diplomatic deep freeze. Now, only one zoo in the U.S. will have giant pandas, but they are expected to return to China next year. 

Tap the link in our bio to read more from @ewongworld about the giant panda legacy in the U.S. and to learn what’s in store for the three pandas making their journey home. Photos by @erinschaff

Andy Beshear, a Democrat, won a second term as Kentucky’s governor on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press. It was a noteworthy victory in a deeply conservative state and one that validated his pragmatic approach during a first term that has been buffeted by a series of natural disasters.

Beshear, 45, one of the most popular governors in the country, led in polls throughout the race. He defeated Daniel Cameron, the state’s attorney general, who is a protégé of Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and who has been considered a rising star in Republican politics. 

Tap the link in our bio to read more about @andybeshearky and the bitterly contested governor’s race in Kentucky. Photo by @jonpcherry

Ohio voters approved a ballot measure on Tuesday to enshrine a right to abortion in the State Constitution, according to The Associated Press. This continues a series of wins for abortion-rights groups that have appealed directly to the public as they try to recover from the U.S. Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade.

Issue 1, as the ballot measure is known, had become a closely followed part of Tuesday’s off-year elections. Both parties are looking to gauge whether voter anger over the loss of the federal right to abortion might help Democrats in next year’s presidential and congressional races. National groups on both sides of the debate poured money into Ohio in recent weeks.

The “yes” vote in Ohio, a conservative-leaning state, is likely to help lift the hopes of abortion-rights groups that are pushing similar measures next year in red and purple states, such as Arizona, South Dakota, Missouri and Florida. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the Ohio vote.

Maybe it’s her grandkids, maybe it’s being 81, but Barbra Streisand is open to new stuff. Take sharing. Well, take sharing about herself.

“My Name Is Barbra,” her first memoir, is upon us. It’s 970 pages and billows with doubt, anger, ardor, hurt, pride, persuasion, glory and Yiddish. “I don’t know that any artist has done more sharing,” writes @wsslyy, a critic at large for The New York Times.

Streisand talked to The Times about her new memoir, exploring the movies and men of her life, and her determination to control her own art. “If you want to read about me in 20 years or 50 years, whatever it is — if there’s still a world — these are my words,” she said. “These are my thoughts.”

Tap the link in our bio to read the full interview with @barbrastreisand, in which she speaks candidly about what’s in her new book. Photo by @ryanpfluger

Kimberly Mata-Rubio, the mother of one of the 19 children killed in the mass shooting last year in Uvalde, Texas, is now running for mayor. 

Mata-Rubio, a former news reporter, would be the first woman and only the third Latino to lead the Hispanic majority city, one that has been bitterly divided in the aftermath of one of the nation’s deadliest mass shootings. 

As president of Lives Robbed, an organization made up of mothers and grandmothers of the Uvalde victims, Mata-Rubio has organized rallies, flown to Washington and sat through legislative hearings in Austin, the Texas capital. Still it did not feel like she was doing enough.

Tap the link in our bio to read why @nicrubio was motivated to run for mayor and what she plans to do if elected. Photo by @tamirhasacellphone

A proposed marine sanctuary in California is facing challenges after a last-minute boundary change to accommodate a wind farm.

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, a 7,573-square-mile area that would include 156 miles of coastline along central California, would limit offshore oil drilling, acoustic underwater testing and other activities. The sanctuary would also provide funding for research and protection to numerous sites, both on and offshore, that are sacred to the Northern Chumash, a tribe that has inhabited California’s coastline for thousands of years.

But the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has thrown a wrench into those plans. In an effort to allow for the development of an offshore wind energy project, NOAA has suggested shifting the sanctuary’s borders to remove a section of the coastline that includes Morro Bay and Morro Rock — or Lisamu’, a site sacred to the Chumash that the tribe has been planning to make the hub of the sanctuary.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the challenges facing the first tribal-led effort in the U.S., which is also guided by Native history, culture and knowledge. Photos by @photographnic

There are unwritten rules when riding the New York City subway.

No eye contact. No blocking doors. No hogging seats.

Three years after the coronavirus nearly wiped out ridership in the nation’s largest transportation network, millions of travelers are reacquainting themselves with transit’s informal customs. The pandemic had suspended these protocols as many passengers stayed home. But now, in a sign that normalcy might be returning, old subway tensions are creeping back as more riders pack into the system.

What are New Yorkers’ top rules for riding the subway? Tap the link in our bio to find out. Photos by @cherkis

Trapped in a territory under siege, Palestinians are documenting and sharing, on Instagram, their harrowing experiences of life under Israeli airstrikes and a ground invasion. One month into the war, @motaz_azaiza and @hindkhoudary have amassed huge followings for their raw and intimate videos. Their posts have led some Israeli media outlets to accuse them of being Hamas propagandists. And yet, Azaiza and Khoudary are living through the war they are covering: surviving intense bombardments, burying their colleagues, watching their homes crumble, and pulling their own families from the rubble.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full story. Video by @nik_olov_ and @yousuralhlou

For more than a century, Lessie Benningfield Randle, one of the last known survivors of the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, has lived with the searing details of that spring. For decades, she has recalled the fire that ravaged her neighborhood, Greenwood, and the frantic trip with her grandmother to the safety of a fairground.

Randle’s 109th birthday is Friday. She was 6 years old when a white mob attacked Greenwood with indiscriminate violence that wrought death and destruction and erased much of the promise of economic stability for future generations. She and the only other known survivor, Viola Fletcher, 109, are united in a historic legal battle to force the City of Tulsa and others to answer for the massacre.

“I would like to see justice. It’s past time. I would like to see this all cleared up and we go down the right road,” Randle said in an interview with The New York Times. “But I do not know if I will ever see that.”

On Monday, a team of lawyers representing Randle, Fletcher and the estate of Fletcher’s younger brother, took what they consider to be the last legal step in their long quest for justice. Tap the link in our bio to read Randle’s full story and to learn about the latest in her legal battle. Photo by @michaelnoblejr

LeVar Burton, who hosted the children’s TV show “Reading Rainbow,” is engaging young audiences again with “Sound Detectives,” a comic mystery podcast that teaches the art of listening.

Burton, who played Geordi La Forge on “Star Trek: The Next Generation” and Kunta Kinte in “Roots,” is best remembered by many parents for “Reading Rainbow.” In the podcast, Burton and his team try to solve a mystery about an errant sound, which they identify, and then interview real-life experts who discuss it.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about @levar.burton’s first podcast for children which, he stressed, he did not see as a long-awaited return to young people’s entertainment. “I don’t feel like I’ve ever left it,” he said. Photo by @arielfish

Hundreds of protestors, led by the activist group Jewish Voice for Peace, rallied in front of the Statue of Liberty on Monday to call for a cease-fire in Gaza.

It was the latest in a series of protests, vigils and other events that Americans on opposing sides of the conflict between Israel and Hamas have organized almost daily in cities across the country since the beginning of the war. Over the weekend, thousands marched in demonstrations in cities including Cincinnati and Provo, Utah, as the death toll in Gaza continued to mount.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the protesters at the Statue of Liberty. Photo by @dave_sanders

In a rally outside Israel’s Parliament, hundreds demand more action on hostages.

Hundreds of people gathered around the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament, in Jerusalem on Monday to demand again that the Israeli government do more to bring hundreds of hostages home — repeating one word, over and over: “Now, now, now.”

It was the latest rally since 242 were kidnapped after Hamas stormed across the border in an attack that killed at least 1,400 people. The hostages include civilians and soldiers from more than 40 countries.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the rally in Israel. Videos by @sergeyponomarev

When @rebeccayarros pitched her publisher a sexy fantasy about telepathic dragons and their riders, she thought it might be a tough sell. However, “Fourth Wing” — an intricately plotted 500-plus-page narrative that takes place at an elite war college as two dragon riders feud, then fall in love — became a huge best seller. And on Tuesday, after much anticipation, the novel’s follow-up, “Iron Flame,” the second installment of a planned five-book series, is scheduled to publish.

The runaway success of “Fourth Wing” stems in part from Yarros’s experience with chronic illness and her life in a military family, which she drew on while crafting the novel.
“Writing Violet is super cathartic, because she struggles to accept the accommodations that are given to her, and I have that same struggle,” Yarros said in an interview with The New York Times.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full profile of Yarros — and to learn about “Fourth Wing” and “Iron Flame.” Photo by @joanna_kulesza

The Golden Gate Bridge, a rare blend of form and function, stands as an engineering marvel, an emblem of Depression-era American muscle. But it has a darker legacy, too: About 2,000 people are known to have died by jumping off the bridge. The true tally is certainly higher, since not all jumps are witnessed and not all bodies are found. 

Such tragedies, officials hope, are mostly in the past. After decades of pleas to raise the rail, workers are nearly finished installing 3.5 miles of stainless-steel nets — a “suicide deterrent system,” officials call it — strung on both sides of the bridge, end to end. The nets, which are nearly invisible from a distance, were chosen to appease those worried about altering the bridge’s iconic look or obstructing its famous views. But the nets can be seen by anyone standing at the rail, hanging about 20 feet down and stretching about 20 feet out. They are taut, marine-grade stainless steel nets meant to withstand the Golden Gate’s combination of rain, wind, salt and fog.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the long fight to make the bridge safer. Photos by @jimwilson125 

If you are having thoughts of suicide, call or text 988 to reach the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline or go to SpeakingOfSuicide.com/resources for a list of additional resources.

Voters in one county in Washington State have picked the winner in every presidential election from Reagan to Biden. What do they think now, a year from Election Day?

Tap the link in our bio to listen to this episode of “The Run-Up” podcast, your guide to the 2024 election, hosted by Astead Herndon.

Video by Astead Herndon, Karen Hanley, Dave Horn and Caitlin O’Keefe/The New York Times

For Donald Trump, a new set of New York Times/Siena College polls captures a stunning, seemingly contradictory picture.

His 91 felony charges in four different jurisdictions have not significantly hurt him among voters in battleground states. Yet he remains weaker than at least one of his Republican rivals, and if he’s convicted and sentenced in any of his cases, some voters appear ready to turn on him — to the point where he could lose the 2024 election.

Trump leads President Biden in five key battleground states — Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, according to the Times/Siena polls. 

Read the full analysis at the link in our bio.

Donald Trump’s trial will continue Monday in a New York courtroom with him on the witness stand, part of a proceeding that threatens the business empire that underpins his public persona and that fostered his run for the White House.

New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, called Trump to the witness stand at his own civil fraud trial in Manhattan, where, under oath and under fire, the former president will try to convince a single skeptical judge — not a jury — that he played no role in the inflation of his net worth to defraud banks and insurers.

Privately, Trump has told advisers that he is not concerned about his time on the stand. He held preparation sessions when he was in New York attending the trial, according to people briefed on the matter. Trump is deeply, personally enraged by this trial — and the fact that his children have had to testify, according to several people who have spoken with him — and he may not be able to restrain himself on the stand.

We’re covering the fraud trial live. Tap the link in our bio for the latest updates. Photo by Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times

Doctors and nurses in Gaza’s teetering hospitals, which are nearing collapse without electricity and basic supplies, say they must now decide which patients get ventilators, who gets resuscitated, or who gets any medical treatment at all. They make snap decisions amid the screams of small children undergoing amputations or brain surgeries without anesthesia or clean water to wash their wounds.

Some veterans of wartime medicine in the Gaza Strip say conditions inside the overcrowded and impoverished territory are the worst they have ever seen, as entire apartment blocks, schools and hospitals crumble under an Israeli bombardment that has left a devastating civilian toll.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the crisis that doctors are facing in Gaza and to get the latest updates on the war. Photos by @samarabuelouf

In his new dark comedy, “Dream Scenario,” Nicolas Cage plays a man who begins popping up in people’s dreams. It’s a metaphor for viral fame that he found cathartic.

“For me, this movie is an interesting analysis about the experience of fame,” said Cage, who called “Dream Scenario” one of the five best scripts he’s ever read. (The others are “Leaving Las Vegas,” which won him the Oscar for best actor, “Raising Arizona,” “Vampire’s Kiss” and “Adaptation.”) 

“When you think of ‘Nic Cage,’ I wanted people to think you were going to see something just a little bit unpredictable, a little bit scary,” he said. “It’s not going to be the same old, same old.”

Read The New York Times’s full interview with Cage at the link in our bio. Photo by @devinyalkin

Israeli Airstrike Hits Residential Area, Gazan Authorities Say

An explosion in Al Maghazi, a densely populated part of the central Gaza Strip, was caused by an Israeli airstrike, the Gazan health ministry said. Video taken in the aftermath shows people searching through the rubble for victims.

Read more about what we know at the link in our bio.

2023 New York City Marathon

New Yorkers turned out in droves to cheer on thousands of runners in the New York City Marathon. Tamirat Tola, the winner in the men’s elite field, broke the course record; Hellen Obiri earned a dramatic victory in the women’s elite field; and Catherine Debrunner and Marcel Hug set records in the wheelchair divisions.

Video by @amirbangs, @benjaminnorman, @hiroko.masuike, @wattsanna_, @adriennegrunwald, @rosemmorton, @claire_sandwich
We asked sex therapists and researchers which myths they wished would go away. Read the eight they talked about — and how they debunked them — at the link in our bio.

Some 50,000 athletes are competing in the New York City Marathon under clear skies and unseasonably warm temperatures, and many more people have lined the race course across all five boroughs to cheer them on.

Marathon Day is something of an unofficial holiday for New York City, as people come out with costumes, cowbells, live music and pun-filled signs to support the runners.

Last year, 47,839 marathoners from 131 countries finished the race. Their average time across the finish line in Central Park was 4 hours 50 minutes 26 seconds.

You can read our earlier coverage of the marathon at the link in our bio. Photos by @rosemmorton, @karstenmoran, Earl Wilson/The New York Times, @hiroko.masuike, @wattsanna_, @adriennegrunwald and @maansi.photo

Tamirat Tola of Ethiopia set a course record in his first New York City Marathon, while Hellen Obiri of Kenya broke away from a pack of elite women at the end of the race for a dramatic victory. Obiri finished in an unofficial time of 2:27:23. Tola finished in an unofficial time of 2:04:59.

Switzerland dominated the wheelchair races. Catherine Debrunner easily won her first New York marathon in a time of 1:39:32, a course record. And Marcel Hug, also of Switzerland, won his third straight men’s race in an unofficial time of 1:25:28. It’s his sixth overall New York victory, a new record, surpassing the five wins of Kurt Fearnley.

Read more of our New York City Marathon coverage at the link in our bio. Photos by Uli Seit for The New York Times.

How U.S. Troops Were Harmed By Firing Their Own Guns

A secret U.S. offensive in 2016 and 2017 used an unusual strategy to fight the Islamic State. The plan: Put a minimal number of American troops on the ground and have them pound the enemy with relentless artillery fire. What no one foresaw was the devastating toll it would take on the troops who did the firing.

Research has started to reveal that as with hits in football, repeated blast exposure from firing heavy weapons may cause irreparable injury to the brain. It is a sprawling problem that the military is just starting to come to grips with.

Dave Philipps of The New York Times spoke to dozens of veterans experiencing mysterious, life-shattering mental and physical problems and investigated a type of brain injury that may have caused the problems.

Video by Dave Philipps, @boatcloak, Rebecca Suner, Ruru Kuo

Blinken Says Cease-Fire in Gaza Would Allow Hamas to Regroup

Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, rebuffed calls from his counterparts in Egypt and Jordan for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza, saying that a halt would allow Hamas to repeat its attack on Israel.

Read more of our live updates on the Israel-Hamas War at the link in our bio.

Thousands of demonstrators filled the streets of Washington and other cities across America on Saturday to protest the scope and scale of Israel’s retaliation in Gaza for last month’s terrorist assault by Hamas.

Saturday’s marches, organized in cities including New York, Nashville, Cincinnati, Las Vegas and San Francisco, extended a stretch of calls for a cease-fire and a lifting of the siege, following widespread demonstrations a week ago in Asian and European capitals.

Read more about the protests and follow our live coverage of the Israel-Hamas War at the link in our bio. Photos by @amirbangs in Washington, @rachelbujalski in San Francisco and @kimraffphoto in Provo, Utah.

New mothers will be starting the New York City Marathon with something helpful speckled along the course: lactation stations.

In addition to lactation tents, there will be a service that allows runners to transport personal nursing pumps from the start area in Staten Island to the finish area in Central Park. Inside the tents, runners will have access to private spaces and hand pumps.

Read more about new moms running marathons and how the New York City Marathon is offering them support at the link in our bio. Photos by @rosemmorton

Severe obesity is the fastest-rising subcategory among youth — “an epidemic within an epidemic,” as the American Academy of Pediatrics calls it.

Pictured here is 16-year-old Alexandra Duerte, who has been living with polycystic ovary syndrome and prediabetes since she was 10. Her doctor suggested bariatric surgery, an operation on the gastrointestinal tract that helps patients lose weight. Alexandra is one of the roughly 20% of children in the U.S. are living with obesity. Some can develop what were once considered adult illnesses: hypertension, diabetes, fatty liver disease. Obesity can also magnify mental-health problems.

How far should doctors go to treat obesity? Read the story at the link in our bio. Photograph by @kholoodeid.

More than 500 runners with disabilities and guides are participating in this year's New York City Marathon. Francesco Magisano is one of them: Sunday will mark the sixth time the 28-year-old, who lost his vision as a teenager, will run the race. 

But long before marathon day, Magisano started breaking in the new guide who will accompany him on the course: Nev Schulman, the producer and host of MTV’s "Catfish" reality TV show,  has run the marathon six times before, but never as a guide. The two men only recently started training together with Achilles, a group of runners with disabilities who met twice a week for runs in Central Park.They run be connected by a running tether that helps them navigate the course together. 

For Schulman, the inspiration to be a guide came during an encounter with an blind runner during a previous marathon. “I hear from behind: ‘Blind runner! Blind runner on your right!’ and two guides guiding what I guess was a 50-something-year-old woman and they just really flew past me,” Schulman said.

Tap the link in our bio to read about how Magisano and Schulman are preparing for the race, where organizers expect 50,000 finishers on Sunday. Photos by @wattsanna_

On Oct. 7, Hamas terrorists staged a surprise attack on Israel, killing roughly 1,400 people in their homes, at a music festival and on the streets. 

For most, the threat dawned immediately. Israelis retreated to safe rooms, monitoring pleas for help they could not answer on WhatsApp, or worrying for hours with no news of loved ones. The events still haunt those who survived. 

Tap the link in our bio to read their stories. Photos by @avishag_sy

"I think this knocked out my head cold," wrote one commenter. Whether you're sick or just in need of something cozy, @alexaweibel's Chicken and Rice Soup With Ginger and Turmeric is at the link in bio. Photo by @johnny_miller_, with food styling by @rebeccajurkevich

Peso Pluma, Mexico’s breakout music star, is bringing an updated version of traditional music to international audiences.

Peso, whose real name is Hassan Emilio Kabande Laija, is the reigning king of corridos tumbados, a modern version of traditional Mexican music, which has found great success over the last couple of years. More than a dozen weeks after the release of Peso’s third album, “Génesis,” it remains in the top 10 on Billboard’s all-genre album chart. On Spotify, his songs have been streamed several billion times.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about @pesopluma and find out which hip-hop artists are currently inspiring him. Photo by @josefinasantos

On Friday, President Biden met with the families of those killed or injured during the rampage last month that claimed the lives of 18 people at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine.

He also met with nurses, local officials and the law enforcement officers who spent two days in a manhunt for the killer. “Jill and I are here on behalf of the American people to grieve with you, and make sure you know that you’re not alone,” Biden said after stopping by a makeshift memorial in Lewiston with his wife, Jill Biden. The president used the opportunity to urge Americans to seek consensus more broadly in the hopes of avoiding more of the spasms of deadly violence that have become a routine part of life in the U.S.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about Biden’s visit to Maine. Photos by @haiyunjiang

The Battle of the Bridge is the biggest football game of the year in Lewiston and Auburn, cities separated by a river in Maine. This season’s matchup came almost exactly a week after a gunman began a shooting spree that killed 18 people and wounded 13 others. 

The game, originally scheduled for last week but played on Wednesday, was a return to routine for the cities after the state’s deadliest mass shooting. It was a chance to celebrate in the open after days of sheltering in place during a terrifying manhunt.

“Long after this game is over, no one is going to remember the score,” said Jason Versey, the Lewiston football coach. “People are going to remember that we came together.”

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the game and how the Lewiston community has come together following the tragedy. Photos by @acullenphoto

Ozempic, and drugs like it, have transformed how doctors treat diabetes and obesity. Now, some psychiatrists are turning to the drugs to counteract the weight gain that often comes with nearly all antipsychotics and some drugs used to treat depression and anxiety.

The New York Times heard from 13 leading mental health facilities and psychiatric departments at major health systems in the U.S. Their responses reflect a new debate in mental health care about whether to prescribe a drug patients will most likely take indefinitely, with only a limited understanding of how people with serious mental illness fare on these medications.

Read more about the debate at the link in our bio.

Art by @derekabella

Scoring a table in New York can seem impossible, but it may be easier than you think. Here’s how the competition played out for one dinner, with tips from the winning players. 

Want to win the restaurant reservation game? Tap the link in our bio. Video by Priya Krishna, Umi Syam, Ruru Kuo/The New York Times

November is officially here and that means more books are on the way.

What books should you watch for this month? Tap the link in our bio to get the full list.

Each September, the ice at the top of the world hits its lowest extent of the year. Researchers are studying how a warming climate is affecting a not-so-frozen ocean.

Read the full story at the link in our bio. Video by Esther Horvath and Claire Hogan/The New York Times

Noa Tishby, once a celebrated actress in Israel, has become a dominant and provocative pro-Israel voice on U.S. television and social media, as well as in print.

She is an unabashed booster of Israel who describes herself as “pro-Palestinian, just anti-Hamas.” She speaks forcefully against a cease-fire in Gaza and against U.S. students and others who have rallied in support of the attack on Israel. Her mission, she says, is to combat global antisemitism and the digital spread of misinformation. To her critics, she can sound like an apologist for the Israeli government. Despite that, she is seemingly everywhere. 

Tap the link in our bio to read the full profile of @noatishby and to learn why she has been described as “the voice of this Jewish generation.” Photo by @markabramsonphoto

Sam Bankman-Fried, founder of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was convicted on Thursday of all seven charges of fraud and conspiracy after a trial that laid bare the hubris and risk-taking across the industry. These counts carry a maximum sentence of 110 years. Bankman-Fried, 31, is expected to appeal.

Bankman-Fried became a symbol of crypto’s excesses last year, when FTX collapsed and he was charged with stealing as much as $10 billion from customers to finance political contributions, venture capital investments and other extravagant spending. His sentencing is set for March 28.

Tap the link in our bio for live updates. Photo by Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times

The evolution of Durham from a faded tobacco town to a diverse cultural and culinary destination has been years in the making. But the ongoing development of this central North Carolina city seems to have reached a new stage. 

The resurgent downtown area — long a transitional neighborhood with pockets of progress — is now brimming with new restaurants, boutiques, bars and breweries. This season, only the brilliant fall foliage can compete with all the terrific food, drink and local color there is to discover across Dur’m, as residents affectionately call the dynamic Bull City.

Planning a trip to Durham? Check out @ingridkwilliams’s full list of recommendations at the link in our bio. Photos by @katemedley

Taylor Tomlinson is about to become not just the only woman to actively host a late-night show on network television, but also the youngest by two decades. Next year, the 29-year-old stand-up comic will take over the time slot after “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” on CBS, as host of "After Midnight."

In a short time, Tomlinson has become one of the most acclaimed and popular stand-up acts in the U.S., building on the strength of two specials on Netflix, “Quarter-Life Crisis” and “Look at You.” She is currently on a global tour of big theaters.

Tap the link in our bio for more on how @taylortomlinson came to get a job that is currently held only by men. Photo by Andrew Levy/Netflix

Of more than 3,000 counties in the U.S., Clallam County in Washington State is the only one that has voted for the winner of the presidential race every year since 1980. The country is a year out from the 2024 presidential election, and despite a robust Republican primary field, the race is looking like it could easily be a 2020 rematch.

@asteadwh, a political reporter for The New York Times, spent a day in the Fairmount Diner in Port Angeles, Washington, talking to a wide range of voters for The Times podcast “The Run-Up.” Tap the link in our bio to see which way these residents are leaning and to listen to the podcast’s first episode of this election cycle. Photos by @granthindsley

On a Saturday in October, in a small foundry, Erin Thompson watched as “a man in heat-resistant attire pulled down his gold-plated visor, turned on his plasma torch and sliced into the face of Robert E. Lee.” The statue had stood in Charlottesville, Va., since 1924 — and had been the subject of incredible controversy. A petition to remove the statue — organized by Zyahna Bryant in 2016 — led to a series of white nationalist rallies held to ensure it remained standing, which ultimately culminated in the death of counterprotester Heather D. Heyer. Now, a group called Swords Into Plowshares is repurposing the statues’ bronze to make a new piece of public art. “The way our communities dispose of these artifacts may influence America’s racial dynamic over the next century, just as erecting them did for the hundred-year period now ending,” @artcrimeprofessor writes. “99 years after the monument’s installation and 158 years after the end of the Civil War, it’s high time we start figuring this out.” Click the link in our bio to read more.| 📷 @ezeamosphotography and @audramelton #nytopinion

For the second year in a row, the number of illegal crossings at the U.S.-Mexico border surpassed two million, according to government data released this month.

The 2022 fiscal year set a record of 2.2 million illegal border crossings. These numbers do not include crossings at official checkpoints. Including those, migrant crossings in the 2023 fiscal year hit a record high.

So why is the number of illegal border crossings so high? Tap the link in our bio to read the full report.

“I don’t really start out to do anything not the biggest possible,” Kim Kardashian said in a new interview with The New York Times. She was, specifically, talking about her shapewear brand, Skims, and how big she wanted it to be.

On Thursday she announced yet another Skims collaboration: a partnership with Swarovski, the Austrian crystal company known for its kitschy animals and rock star customizations. Founded four years ago, Skims went from being valued at $1.6 billion in 2021 to $4 billion last summer. In between, it became the official underwear outfitter of Team U.S.A. for the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, and won the 2022 Innovation Award from the Council of Fashion Designers of America. Last month, it introduced a men’s line. 

Tap the link in our bio to read @vvfriedman’s full interview with @kimkardashian in which she talks about the newest collaboration, the future of Skims and how she thinks she has “evolved from the 2000s.” Photo by @sheekswinsalways

Artem Dymyd, Dmytro Paschuk and Roman Lozynskyi were childhood friends, growing up together in Lviv, Ukraine. Life took them in separate directions, but when Russia invaded their country last year, all three volunteered to fight and found themselves in the same unit on the front lines.

@meganspecia, an international correspondent at The New York Times, spent a year following the paths of these friends as they went to war. At the link in our bio, read the story of how their brotherhood was shaped by war. Photos by @EmileDucke, @laetitiavancon, @hoffmanbrendan and Roman Lozynskyi

For the first time in their 63-year history, the Texas Rangers became World Series champions on Wednesday when they defeated the Arizona Diamondbacks in Game 5.

The final score was 5-0, with the Rangers scoring four runs in the ninth inning. 

“After suffering what was perhaps the most brutal World Series defeat in baseball history, and certainly the closest that any of the previously ringless teams have ever come to winning it, they’ve finally done it,” Grant Brisbee writes for @theathletichq. “You do, in fact, have to hand it to them.”

Tap the link in our bio to read the full analysis of the game from The Athletic. Photo by Jamie Squire/Getty Images

Bobby Knight, one of college basketball’s signature coaches and a singular personality renowned for his tempestuousness and hubris, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Indiana. He was 83.

His death was announced in a statement on his website. It did not give a cause.

Mercurial and volatile, Knight was among the most polarizing characters in American sports. He was a brilliant coach who sought out intelligent players, deployed a ferocious man-to-man defense, extolled the virtues of precision passing and preached the necessities of never-ending hustle. Known as a principled perfectionist and a master teacher, he was also a driven competitor for whom losing was agony and a relentless motivator whose chief tool, it often seemed, was the anger-fueled rant.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about Knight, who found fame, glory and notoriety at Indiana University, where he was head coach for 29 years. Photo by Barton Silverman/The New York Times

Tracking the Start of the Israeli Invasion of Northern Gaza

After an air campaign that killed thousands of Palestinians, Israel began a ground assault, but it took hours for outside observers to understand what was happening. Satellite imagery taken on Oct. 30 shows the substantial scale of one of Israel’s main advances into northern Gaza, where hundreds of armored vehicles have pushed miles past the border into urban areas on the outskirts of Gaza City.

More than 8,000 Palestinians have been killed in airstrikes since Israel began retaliating, according to Gaza’s Hamas-run ministry of health. Tap the link in our bio to read the full story.

Meg Ryan has always had reservations about the rom-com genre that brought her megastar status in the ’80s and ’90s. With her new movie, “What Happens Later,” a wily rom-com that she co-wrote, starred in and directed, she is pushing the genre’s boundaries to examine vulnerable issues of aging and love.

Returning to the genre at this point in her career is both safe and gutsy. She knows how to play the beats – and how to deflect them, too. But Ryan, 61, may also face exponential scrutiny for her choices, her humor, her looks, her very state of being. That, too, doesn’t seem to faze her. “My interest in this movie isn’t about Hollywood’s perception of me,” she said. “I’m not interested in controlling that. I don’t think I can.”

Tap the link in our bio to hear more from @megryan on how she punctures the rom-com genre in her upcoming film. Photo by @chantalaanderson

It’s officially November, so here’s an idea for your Thanksgiving table: Stuffed Onions from @thisiskaychun. Take a look at the link in bio! (Photo: @christophertestani, food styling: @simoncooks, prop styling: @christinalane1)

In recent weeks, the Pakistani government abruptly declared that all foreign citizens living in the country without documents must leave by Nov. 1. 

The 1.7 million Afghans living illegally in Pakistan have come under mounting pressure, according to human rights groups and migrants. So far, more than 70,000 Afghans have left. Landlords have evicted Afghan tenants, fearing large fines if they don’t. Employers have fired undocumented Afghan workers. The police have raided neighborhoods popular among Afghans, arresting those without paperwork.

Rights groups have condemned Pakistan’s actions, worried about the possibility that some Afghans could face persecution in Afghanistan for past ties to Taliban opponents. Meanwhile, Pakistani officials have established several deportation centers nationwide. Many Afghans have faced devastating decisions about whether to try to stay in a country where they are no longer welcome or return to one where they have not lived for decades.

Tap the link in our bio to read about the dilemma Afghans currently face in Pakistan. Photos by @eliseblchrd

Tens of thousands of buildings in Gaza, including at least a quarter of all buildings in northern Gaza, appear damaged or destroyed, according to an analysis of satellite imagery. The assessment offers a newly detailed picture of the widespread devastation caused by the Israeli bombardment of Gaza in the past several weeks.

While only an estimate, the spatial analysis indicates the enormous destructiveness of Israel’s bombing campaign, which has become one of the most intense of the 21st century. Israeli strikes in Gaza have killed more than 8,000 people, according to Gazan health officials.

We’re covering the war live at the link in our bio.

Some people with dual nationalities and seriously injured Palestinians arrived in Egypt on Wednesday, Egyptian state-owned TV said, as the Gaza border opened for the first such crossings since the start of the war between Hamas and Israel. Three critically injured people from Gaza arrived at an Egyptian hospital near the border, a hospital official said.

The crossings came after a deal negotiated late Tuesday among Israel, Egypt, Hamas, the U.S. and Qatar. Egypt was set to receive hundreds of people on Wednesday, according to Western diplomats in Cairo and Jerusalem and the Gaza authorities.

We’re covering the war live at the link in our bio. Video by Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

The number of homeless public school students in New York City reached an all-time high of 119,320 last school year, according to new data released Wednesday, as migrants crossing the southern border continued to flock to the city. Since last summer alone, more than 30,000 new students in temporary housing have enrolled in city schools, including some 12,000 in the last five months who were not reflected in the data.

The statistics — which include children in shelters, hotels, relatives’ homes and other transient places — illuminate the challenges for Mayor Eric Adams’s administration in handling the rise in homeless students. As the system’s overall enrollment shrinks, the rise in homelessness among children means the issue has touched more schools. Now, about 1 in 9 New York City students are homeless. Some areas of the city have been especially hard hit, however. In one section of the Bronx, more than 22% of students were homeless.

Tap the link in our bio to read about how the city is responding to the growing number of homeless students. Photo by @wattsanna_

Heidi Klum transformed into a giant human peacock on Tuesday night for her Halloween bash in New York City. The model and former host of “Project Runway” talked about her costumed performance in an exclusive interview with The New York Times.

She is known for the elaborate outfits she wears every Halloween, and this year she had help from 10 Cirque du Soleil performers. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Klum’s transformation and to see costumes from earlier years. Photo by @kristaschlueter
